title: The quiet, pervasive devaluation of frontend
author: Josh Collinsworth
description: Nodding in agreement with every paragraph here.

title: The environmental benefits of privacy-focussed web design
author: Root Web Design Studio
description: It's like they wrote this specifically for me. The cross section of privacy and sustainability is right up my alley.

title: Bookmarklets for testing your website
author: Jeremy Keith
description: I always forget that bookmarklets are a thing, and these are some great ones to save.

title: Thoughts on embedding alternative text metadata into images
author: Eric Bailey
description: Context matters, and standardizing a new image format that includes alternative text is unrealistic. Writing alt text with the tools that already exist is much more sensible.

title: Use your Mac the way I do: a thought experiment
author: Blake Watson
description: First person account of how Blake, who has spinal muscular atrophy, uses his Mac with only a mouse.

title: Time to Ditch Analytics? Tracking Scripts and Web Sustainability
author: Michelle Barker
description: Another reason to drop analytics and third-party scripts: they waste energy.

title: The Cost of a Tool
author: Edward Loveall
description: The harm from AI has nothing to do with creating infinite paperclips and everything to do with undermining labor, stealing from artists, and wasting tremendous amounts of resources.

title: The growing backlash against AI
author: tante/Jürgen Geuter
description: Call me a luddite, I'm ready to smash the machines.

title: Modernizing Your Application: Where to Begin
author: Jason Grigsby
description: It's tempting to burn it all down and start fresh, but that's rarely the best option. This guide is a good starting point for people trying to figure out a strategy for upgrading a legacy system.

title: Write CSS. Not too much. Mostly scoped.
author: Lee Reamsnyder
description: CSS is way easier now than it used to be, and most of the issued I've run into with CSS came from there being way too much of it. This generalized advice is pretty solid for folks who want to escape the Tailwind/CSS-in-JS ecosystem created by people afraid of CSS.

title: On popover accessibility: what the browser does and doesn't do
author: Hidde de Vries
description: It's always good to know the details about new browser features and what you can expect when you start using them in the wild.

title: The one about the web developer job market
author: Baldur Bjarnason
description: It's rough out there, and the combination of an inflating AI bubble and an already bad job market has me worried about the inevitable fallout in the next few years or months, even.

title: Local-First Web Development
description: A collection of tools and techniques to build products that work on end user devices regardless of connectivity. This approach could also improve privacy and data-ownership, so I definitely want to tinker with some ideas around that.

title: Youtube video embedding harm reduction
author: Julien Voisin
description: Maybe don't embed or include anything from a Google-owned domain if you can avoid it.

title: Front-end development's identity crisis
author: Elly Loel
description: It should be enough to specialize in HTML, CSS, and JS, especially when you consider the design, experience, and accessibility work that goes into front-end development. Making "full-stack" the default does a disservice to both front-end and back-end developers.

title: AI hallucinates software packages and devs download them - even if potentially poisoned with malware
author: Thomas Claburn at The Register
description: An evolution from typo-squatting attacks, made possible by the AI-generated hell that's being built around us. Stay safe out there and don't let spicy autocomplete write your code for you.

title: a11yphant
description: Interactive, focused tutorials that teach you how to build accessible websites. I've been wanting to build something along these lines, and I wish more things like this existed to teach developers the craft instead of funneling them into React-land.

title: all-about-computer-love.glitch.me
description: I love art pieces like this that use the medium of the web in unexpected (or unintended) ways.

title: How we're approaching theming with modern CSS
author: Andy Bell
description: CSS custom properties are so perfect for this sort of thing. They unlock so much flexibility while letting you have sensible defaults using fallbacks.

title: An Interactive Guide to CSS Container Queries
author: Ahmad Shadeed
description: Container queries are so good, and Ahmad is one of the best in the biz for breaking down how to use them.

title: What I think about when I edit
author: Eva Parish
description: Say exactly what you mean and take out all unnecessary words.

title: Testing HTML With Modern CSS
author: Heydon Pickering
description: Using CSS as a strategy for sniffing out bad HTML is brilliant. A bookmarklet is probably the sensible approach, but I'm tempted to bake these sorts of things into styling resets.

title: Mario meets Pareto
author: Antoine Mayerowitz
description: Maybe don't read this if you just want to have fun playing Mario Kart rather than optimizing it to hell. I am unfortunately a min-maxer, though.

title: When security and accessibility clash: why are banking applications so inaccessible?
author: Nic Chan
description: No, arbitrarily making your application harder to use does not make it more secure.

title: AI isn't useless. But is it worth it?
author: Molly White
description: Unlike cryptocurrency, AI is actually useful for some things, but between the ethical issues, the effects on human labor, and the extraordinary environmental costs, I can't justify using it.

title: The 10x Programmer Myth
author: Justin Etheridge
description: I'd like to think I'm a Rocket Turtle, but I think I'm more of a mix of an Obsessor and a Simplifier.

title: How social networks prey on our longing to be known
author: Jan Maarten
description: Turns out trading privacy for free or cheap software may have been a bad idea.

title: The creepy sound of online trackers
author: Per Axbom
description: Knowing how invasive some sites are is quite different from hearing it firsthand.

title: The Aura of Care.
author: Stephen Farrugia
description: Weird how UX and accessibility recommendations seem to only be considered when it will make the business money.

title: Testing and Improving a Roku App's Accessibility
author: Dustin Whisman
description: Oh look, I wrote this one. Long story short, we have it easy as web developers.

title: Heat Death of the Internet
author: Gregory Bennett
description: An all too relatable slice of life story going through our current internet dystopia.

title: React, Electron, and LLMs have a common purpose: the labour arbitrage theory of dev tool popularity
author: Baldur Bjarnason
description: It's never sat right with me that React/Next.js just sort of became the default because that's what developers know, and this piece finally articulates why it's bothered me (apart from poor craftsmanship).

title: Help us invent CSS Grid Level 3, aka "Masonry" layout
author: Jen Simmons
description: I have a tiny bit of masonry layout on my site (when it's supported), but the examples here really express just how wild you can go with the experimental version currently behind flags and tech preview builds.

title: An alternative proposal for CSS masonry
author: Rachel Andrew
description: Does masonry work better as part of grid or does it deserve it's own separate implementation? I don't have strong preferences, so long as it works reliably across browsers soon.

title: The perfect site doesn't exist
author: Michelle Barker
description: "Move slow and mend things" and treat websites as gardens to be tended to. An excellent way to think about building sustainably.

title: Modern WordPress - Yikes!
author: David Bushell
description: This is a good summary of all the weirdness involved with building WordPress themes using their peanut-butter-in-chocolate strategy for mixing languages and databases.

title: Copyright
author: David Bushell
description: David's AI license is a great weaponization of the opt-out strategy that companies training LLMs are using.

title: Why Patching Globals Is Harmful
author: Artem Zakharchenko
description: We have Array.flat() instead of Array.flatten() because MooTools changed globals they didn't own. Next.js is doing the same sort of thing with fetch.

title: On compliance vs readability: Generating text colors with CSS
author: Lea Verou
description: Being able to automatically pick the best contrast color in CSS would be great, and these techniques get us pretty close until contrast-color() is widely supported.

title: Known Purpose and Trusted Potential.
author: Stephen Farrugia
description: OpenAI can't make ChatGPT more accurate or reliable, so the only way they can improve "performance" is to make it faster and more confident. Keep an eye out for faked/trivial demos. Are there actual use cases where inaccuracy or lack of supervision is acceptable?

title: If Kevin Roose Was ChatGPT With A Spray-On Beard, Could Anyone Tell?
author: Albert Burneko
description: Maybe don't listen to people who are consistently wrong about things all the time.

title: The deskilling of web dev is harming the product but, more importantly, it's damaging our health - this is why burnout happens
author: Baldur Bjarnason
description: Full-stack developers have ruined the quality of the web (and the job market), just look at my evaluations of the top 100 US websites.

title: Privacy Disasters: Microsoft, Just Because You Can
author: Carey Lening
description: Microsoft's new Recall product is just such an obvious privacy/security nightmare, how did it ever get past the brainstorming phase?

title: How it feels to get an AI email from a friend
author: Neven Mrgan
description: Don't be like this friend. If you want to automate boring corporate emails, I can understand that, but friendly communication? C'mon.

title: Visual design rules you can safely follow every time
author: Anthony Hobday
description: An excellent set of rules of thumb that you can use to make sure your designs don't look terrible.

title: What Do We Want Computers to Do?
author: Louie Mantia
description: I'd rather computers help humans do things and automate mundane tasks. To be clear, creating art is not a mundane task.

title: Opinions for Writing Good CSS
author: Andrew Walpole
description: These are some good basic rules, but I especially agree with "don't paste CSS." You gotta understand how the properties build on each other to understand the full picture.

title: switching.software
description: A handy resource for finding alternatives to problematic software. Especially useful after recent high profile terms of use update fuckery.

title: Succor borne every minute
author: Michael Atleson
description: The FTC has been doing great antitrust work recently, and they're absolutely willing to take on issues with AI. Hell yeah.

title: Hello My Beautiful Creatures (2.5 hour video)
author: Joel Haver
description: Joel is an incredibly ambitious film maker who decided to make 12 movies in 2024, and on top of that, he decided to make one of them a 2.5 hour STOP MOTION movie. It also wasn't planned way in advance. He and his collaborators just kind of figured it out as they went, which is incredible, given how well the final result works.

title: ooh.directory
author: Phil Gyford
description: This is a collection of thousands of blogs about all kinds of topics, all human-made and free of SEO chicanery and AI slop.

title: Theme Machine
author: Keith J. Grant
description: Always on the lookout for a good color picker and palette generator, and this does both with support for p3 colors like OKLCH.

title: A Structured Approach to Custom Properties
author: Keith J. Grant
description: This approach to setting up design tokens makes a lot of sense and balances ease of use with consistency. Definitely going to refer back to this when setting up new projects.

title: It's about time I tried to explain what progressive enhancement actually is
author: Andy Bell
description: In case you've heard people talk about progressive enhancement but don't have a good handle on what that actually means or how to build things that way.

title: New Web Development. Or, why Copilots and chatbots are particularly bad for modern web dev
author: Baldur Bjarnason
description: When the only jobs are for senior React devs, how are junior devs supposed to learn the fundamentals? Leaving that to chatbots that are trained on outdated StackOverflow answers and make shit up all the time seems like a bad idea.

title: It's really this thing that gets me.
author: Chris Coyier
description: If accessibility overlays actually worked, they'd be sold to users who would benefit from using them on all websites, not to companies as compliance shields.

title: Story Points are Pointless, Measure Queues
author: Barry Jones
description: Story points are confusing, inconsistent, and frequently misused, so maybe instead of talking about whether a story is 3 points or 5 points, we should talk about the details of the work that needs to be done.

title: A handful of reasons JavaScript won't be available
author: Andy Bell
description: Of course it's never been a safe assumption that the most brittle language out of HTML, CSS, and JS will be available, and yet it's used to do everything for far too many sites.

title: The Anchor Element
author: Heydon Pickering
description: Some really lovely metaphors in here. I really hope this turns into a series about all the major HTML elements.

title: Cascade Layers are useless*
author: Manuel Matuzović
description: *if you don't understand the problems they solve. This is a nice, brief explanation of what Cascade Layers are for and how to combine them with other approaches to make authoring CSS easier.

title: Plain Vanilla
description: I'd like to see more resources like this to help move web development away from complex frameworks. Browsers are good now! Use the platform!

title: Nation Wary Of Suddenly Usable Website
author: The Onion
description: Good to see The Onion returning to form after being hollowed out by corporate owners over the past decade.

title: Good sabotage for bad robots
author: Jan Maarten
description: A handy collection of tools and techniques for blocking robots from drinking your milkshake.

title: Reckoning (4 part series)
author: Alex Russell
description: Required reading for people who are also tired of the JavaScript industrial complex and need some hard data to change minds.

title: P(Dumb)
author: Dorian Taylor
description: A really good breakdown of what machine learning and LLMs are capable of now and what would actually need to happen before AI doomsday scenarios to be realistic. If someone is talking about AI risks and they mean paperclips, you can ignore them. Let's focus on misinformation, creative theft, and non-consensual AI-generated porn first.
